pageTitle: UTA's police dispatchers vital to safety
shortDescription: Join the UTA Police Department in recognizing the department's dispatchers during Public Safety Telecommunicators' Week, April 8-14.Public safety tele
body:
Join the UTA Police Department in recognizing the department's dispatchers during Public Safety Telecommunicators' Week, April 8-14.

Public safety telecommunicators, or dispatchers, are vital to the police department’s ability to serve the University community. Eight dispatchers and one communications supervisor staff UTA’s Police Communications Center 24 hours a day, seven days a week to ensure vital systems are monitored and a professional line of communication with our community is consistently available.

The UTA Police Communications Center answers and processes approximately 8,000 emergency and non-emergency calls for service each month. Dispatchers coordinate the response of police and public safety officers, manage approximately 1,500 monthly queries into the FBI criminal justice information system, monitor burglar and fire alarms, and provide valuable information to students, faculty, staff, and visitors to the UTA campus.

pageTitle: Induction ceremony for UTA’s Military Science Hall of Honor
shortDescription: One former Army ROTC cadet and two former commanders at The University of Texas at Arlington will be inducted into the Military Science Hall of Honor
body:
One former Army ROTC cadet and two former commanders at The University of Texas at Arlington will be inducted into the Military Science Hall of Honor on Saturday, March 24.

Retired Lt. Cols. Mark Latham, Max Manifold, and Lora Rimmer will be honored at 3 p.m. in the Rosebud Theatre of the E.H. Hereford University Center, 300 W. First St. A retreat ceremony and firing of the Carlisle Cannons are at 3:30 p.m. on the Library mall. A performance by the Sam Houston Rifles Drill Team and a reception with cadets is followed by a dinner at 5:30 p.m.

Latham (’76 BA, Political Science) was a member of the Sam Houston Rifles and a corps commander. After a tour in Germany, he transitioned to Special Forces, taught at the Command and General Staff College, and served in high-level staff positions in Washington, D.C. and Europe. He retired in 2004.

 Manifold enlisted in 1940 and earned a Silver Star while with the 2nd Ranger Battalion. He served in five major campaigns, including Korea and Vietnam. Manifold joined the Military Science Department at Arlington State College in 1960 and was the sponsor for the Sam Houston Rifles. After retiring in 1968, he was a veteran counselor for federal and state programs.

 Rimmer served with the Signal Corps in tours in Kuwait and Iraq. She became the first female commander of UTA’s ROTC program in 2011. In 2014, she was named the Military Science Professor of the Year, a national honor. She retired in 2015.

The UTA Military Science Hall of Honor was established in 1980 to recognize the achievements of those who participated in Army ROTC and were members of the Corps of Cadets, or who made significant contributions to the Corps of Cadets by their service. The Hall has more than one hundred members and is sponsored by the 115th Maverick Battalion and the Cadet Corps Alumni Council.

shortDescription: University College will be renamed the Division of Student Success, a part of UTA's Academic Affairs, effective March 15.Ashley Purgason has been name
body:
University College will be renamed the Division of Student Success, a part of UTA's Academic Affairs, effective March 15.

Ashley Purgason has been named associate vice provost for the division. Dr. Purgason previously served as assistant vice president for strategic initiatives in the Office of the President, and she was assistant dean for undergraduate research and student advancement in the College of Science. She teaches courses in biology.

The division will continue to be a focal point for first-year students and play an important role in their development, learning, and success. The new division will actively collaborate with schools and colleges to deploy academic support services. Additionally, the unit will help returning learners and students seeking to complete their degrees in a timely manner.

The Division of Student Success is located in Ransom Hall and is home to the University Advising Center, the McNair Scholars Program, Trio-Student Support Services, University Tutorial and Supplemental Instruction, Testing Services, and University Studies. The division is sponsors programming such as the Success Series workshops, Freshman Interest Groups, the Resource Hotline, and Success U.

The Interdisciplinary Studies program will move to the Honors College under the direction of Interim Dean Kevin Gustafson. Interdisciplinary Studies provides students the opportunity to develop individualized programs of study—often in conjunction with existing certificates and minors—to meet their personal, academic, and professional goals.

body:
Experience the innovative plays of the Maverick Theatre Company’s MavLab, The Rise and Rise of Daniel Rocket and Grace. Productions are Thursday-Sunday, March 22-25, and are rated PG-13.

C.C. Weatherly directs The Rise and Rise of Daniel Rocket by Peter Parnell. Surrounded by taunting peers, Daniel Rocket finds the strength to literally fly above them all in a tale of youth, loneliness, and the power of believing in others as well as yourself.

Performers are Sarah Boone, Karla Zamora, Gage Anderson, Brian Hughes, Hannah Hackley, Samantha Shepherd, Darcy Doyle, Kace Owens, Jeremy Claycamp, and Cody Jackson. Researchers in the College of Liberal Arts (CoLA) discuss the results of their projects in “From Cure to Care” (iC2C)" noon-1:45 p.m. Monday, April 2, in the sixth floor atrium of the Central Library.

In 2017, CoLA awarded six seed grants under its new research initiative “From Cure to Care” (iC2C): Advancing Human Well-being through Arts, Humanities, and Social Sciences."

Maria Martinez-Cosio, associate vice provost for Faculty Affairs, will moderate the panel discussions on each project.

• Charles Travis and Andrew Milson, History, "Humanities GIS: Deep Mapping Health, the Human Condition and Climate Change in the American Southwest and Sub-Saharan Africa"

• Daniel Sledge and Herschel Thomas, Political Science, "Mapping the Politics of Public Health: Threat Perception, Advocacy, and Policymaking"

• Amanda Alexander, Matt Clark, Mark Clive, Art and Art History; Angela Liegey-Dougall and Perry Fuchs, Psychology, College of Science; "Artopia: Creative Healing"

1-1:45 p.m.

• Thomas Christie, Brian Horton, Karishma Chatterjee, Tom Ingram, Shelley Wigley, Communication, "Perceptions of HPV Pharmaceutical Marketing Messages Among College Youth"

• Charla Markham-Shaw, Karishma Chatterjee, Chyng-yang Jang, Communication, "The Roles of Peer Networks and Social Media in Information Seeking and Adoption of HPV Vaccine."
